answerText: methyl group[10] Both Sn1 and Sn2 reactions hinge on the use of one of these substituents, which are initially bonded to the electrophilic carbon but ultimately depart. Tosylate and mesylate are excellent examples of these types of substituents.
heading: NASAT |2013 | 4 | 20 | Science | Chemistry | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Answer some questions about Sn2 reactions in organic chemistry. For 10 points each: [10] An Sn2 reaction is quite unfavorable if the electrophilic carbon has three of these simple alkyl groups bonded to it. This group is composed of a carbon bonded to three hydrogens.
